awd_titl_txt: Peroxy Acids as Emerging Disinfectants for Water Treatment: Oxidation Chemistry Elucidation and Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Science Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Ching-Hua Huang of the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta seeks to better understand peroxy acids (POAs) as emerging disinfectants and oxidants to replace chlorine in wastewater treatment facilities. Despite the growing interest and pilot- to full-scale implementation of POAs in wastewater treatment, the understanding POAs trails behind their applications. The objective of this project is to provide a comprehensive understanding of the chemistry of POAs in water. This project has multiple broader impacts. It establishes an active collaboration with industry partners in evaluating on-going field tests of POA-based processes. The research enhances graduate and undergraduate student education by promoting the participation of underrepresented groups. The new knowledge and improved POAs-based technology benefits society by providing in safe water treatment technology, clean water and sanitation, and smart water management.  All of the applications protect human health and the ecosystem.

The intellectual contribution of this study is to provide new fundamental knowledge on the chemistry of POAs and their radical-based advanced oxidation processes.  Such processes may effectively destroy water pollutants. Specific research aims include: investigating the chemical oxidation of organic micropollutants, biomolecules and structurally representative compounds by POAs; characterizing the ultraviolet (UV)/POA process; investigating the degradation of organic micropollutants and biomolecules under UV/POA; assessing the water matrix effect on the POA and UV/POA processes; developing kinetic modeling for the POA and UV/POA processes; and performing quantum chemical evaluation of oxidation reactions by POAs and UV/POA. The new knowledge improves the POA and UV/POA technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Peroxy acids (POAs) are a group of green oxidants with the potential to replace chlorine in wastewater treatment facilities as emerging disinfectants and oxidants. Peracetic acid (PAA) is the most commonly used POAs at commercial scale. This project conducted systematic and extensive investigation to address the need to improve the fundamental knowledge of POAs, regarding their intrinsic reactivity with organic and biological pollutants, the application potential of POAs for water treatment, and the advanced oxidation process (AOP) based on activated POAs for effective removal of water pollutants.

The outcomes of intellectual merits of this project include: (1) an extensive review and new knowledge of the reactivity of PAA with a wide range of different organic compounds; (2) an in-depth mechanistic and kinetic characterization of the UV/PAA AOP and development of the first kinetic model for this system; (3) demonstration of the effectiveness of UV/PAA to degrade various organic pollutants and inactivate indicator microorganisms in environmental water samples; (4) evaluation of interactions of PAA with common metal ions for potential AOPs; and (5) elucidation of the reactive species generated by PAA-based AOPs for enhanced water decontamination and disinfection. These results are significant in opening new applications and guiding current practice of POAs in water treatment processes. The improved fundamental knowledge and new modeling tool from this project will help design and optimize the POAs and UV/POA processes in water treatment systems. The findings of this project have helped build a stronger foundation to further improve and develop POA-based technologies for water treatment.

The outcomes of the broader impacts of this project are in several aspects. First, this project organized a successful workshop centered on POAs for water treatment and attracted a broad participation of industry, academia, public utilities and government agencies. The event increased the attention to the emerging technology of POAs and stimulated more industry-academia knowledge exchange and collaboration. Second, this project trained a broad range of students, from high schoolers to postdocs, in POAs related chemistry and engineering processes and in water quality engineering broadly. The results are also widely disseminated through 12 high-impact journal publications and 19 technical presentations at may international conferences and universities. Finally, the research results of this project provide a critical basis to facilitate optimal development of POA applications in the field of water and wastewater treatment. The knowledge is also beneficial and useful to a few other fields such as food and medical industries that currently utilize POAs heavily.
